Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Engineering biodegradable performance fibers for textiles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to support the development of biodegradable performance fibers with inherent color and material performance that can be attributed to protein structure for the fashion and textile industry. This product addresses the fashion and textile industryâ€™s concerns over the environmental impacts of petroleum-based synthetic fibers (polyester, nylon, spandex, etc.) as an extractive raw material source that persists in the environment as microplastics. The proposed fiber manufacturing offers a valuable alternative to conventional textile dyeing, the second largest sources of water pollution, and textile finishing, a source of environmental volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and human health hazards.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a platform for engineering proteins with a desired function (color, stretch, and moisture management) and enzymatically cross-linking them into a fiber for textile applications. The technology enzymatically cross-links engineered proteins that are expressed and amplified in E. Coli or yeast. The protein-based fibers are selected, or designed, to map a desired textile property into a functional fiber, film or biopolymer raw material suitable for industrial spinning processes. These engineered proteins are designed to address the demands of the textile industry by providing attributes such as inherent color and stretch to the fibers. Proof-of-concept has been demonstrated in the development of biopolymer composite fibers with inherent color and fluorescence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last few years  our major activities have focused on understanding our supply chain, market, and customer. We’ve continued conversations and have conducted interviews with brands/customers in the departments of raw material sourcing, sustainability, innovation, and production. We attended the Textile Exchange Conference in 2022, where we learned about upcoming regulations for the textile industry and certifications required for new material companies. We also met with brands and manufacturers across the supply chain. A major activity for us was to visit mills around the world in person such as fiber manufacturers, spinners, knitters, and dyers. This helped us understand processing requirements for our fibers such as temperature, speed, ph, chemicals, etc. We’ve continued to meet with founders and key stakeholders of new material companies to understand how they’ve grown to scale, and have begun identifying R&D and production partners. We’ve conducted over 250 interviews to date and through these conversations we’ve continued to test our hypotheses of our customers top three pain points and Werewool’s value proposition that addresses our customers pain points. 

Our objectives were to continue validating our value propositon for our customers and test the top three pain points for our customers when sourcing new materials that we’ve identified and continue to test are: 1) the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions,  2) the need for biodegradable fibers due to issues with micro-plastic pollution, 3) finding alternatives to conventional dyeing processes that reduce toxic chemical and water usage throughout the supply chain. 

We also wanted to identify and refine our business model (B2B2C) and identify development partners throughout the supply chain. The textile exchange conference was beneficial to us as we were finally able to connect with stakeholders in person. We were also looking to understand Joint Development Partnerships and Offtake Agreements, as these will be our first sources of revenue. Another hypothesis we were looking to validate is that as government regulations increase, and brands increasingly define commitments to climate positivity goals, there exists a timely opportunity for Werewool to reach customers in a B2B2C model.

Through our customer interviews and continued conversations we have obtained NDA’s and Letters of Support from large and small brands as well as supply chain partners. We have engaged with CMO’s for protein production, and have begun fiber production in external wet spinning facilities. We have also connected with garment manufacturers in the apparel/accessory industry, and have brought some of them on to our advisory board. 

We have a much clearer understanding of the supply chain and understand the limitations and barriers to entry. Our cost hypothesis of a 15-20% increase for new materials has continued to be validated, but some brands are absorbing an even higher cost. Where we have seen athletic apparel brands using a bio based nylon which goes for $22-$24/kg. We have also identified certifications that are most important to our customers. With all of these lessons learned and key outcomes we have been able to refine our market differentiation, validate our value proposition, understand cost tolerance, refine our business model, and identify key development partners. 

We closed our first round of seed funding in March 2023, and have grown our team, and built out our own lab and office space at SUNY Downstate's Incubator. 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2024
Modified by: Theanne Schiros
